question: You are a code expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Make sure the code you generate is executable whenever possible. Please implement a multi-track video editor that allows users to add video, audio, and subtitles on different tracks. Users should be able to independently control the order, volume, and visibility of each track, and finally export all tracks as a single composite video file.

checklist.title: Is the multi-track timeline interface fully implemented?
checklist.description: Review whether the code accurately implements a timeline with multiple independent tracks through HTML/JavaScript, and whether it includes proper track visualization, time markers, and zooming capabilities. Score 0 if the timeline interface is not implemented, 5 if it's basic without zooming or customization, and 10 if it includes features like time markers, snap-to-grid, and customizable track heights.

checklist.title: Are the track types (video, audio, subtitle) properly implemented with appropriate controls?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code provides distinct track types with appropriate controls for each: videos should have opacity/visibility toggles, audio tracks should have volume controls and waveform visualization, subtitles should have text editing and timing controls. Deduct 3 points if any track type is missing, 3 points if track-specific controls are incomplete, and 2 points if the visualization is inadequate. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the media import and parsing functionality properly implemented?
checklist.description: Check whether the code handles importing various media formats (mp4, webm, mp3, wav, srt, vtt), extracts metadata (duration, resolution, codec), generates previews/thumbnails for video content, and parses subtitle files correctly. Deduct 3 points for each media type not supported, 3 points if preview generation is missing, and 4 points if metadata extraction is incomplete. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the video export and rendering pipeline implemented?
checklist.description: Assess whether the code implements a proper rendering pipeline that combines all tracks (video, audio, subtitles) into a single output file with appropriate settings for resolution, framerate, and format selection. The implementation should include progress tracking and error handling. Deduct 5 points if only client-side preview is available without actual export, 5 points if the export lacks format options, and 3 points if there's no progress tracking. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle common abnormal situations (such as unsupported file formats, corrupted media files, browser memory limitations, etc.) and provide friendly error prompts or recovery mechanisms. Code with strong robustness should be able to effectively handle these edge cases, giving 10 points. If the robustness is average, give 5 points, and if no exceptions are handled, give 0 points.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the experience (e.g., 1. AI-assisted editing suggestions 2. Auto-synchronization of audio tracks 3. Voice-to-text for automatic subtitle generation 4. Transition effects library). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementation of similar functions (e.g., multiple playback controls with overlapping functionality) 2. Function modules unrelated to video editing (e.g., built-in social media sharing) 3. Fancy effects that affect performance (e.g., unnecessarily complex animations in the UI). Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if the core functions are interfered with by redundant code.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as separating media processing/timeline/UI layers), unit test coverage, and build process automation. Deduct 5 points if global state pollution is found or design patterns are not used; deduct 5 points if the code duplication rate is too high (over 30%); deduct 5 points if the build process is not automated. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional design standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the overall design follows professional video editor UI principles: 1) Dark theme optimized for media viewing 2) Clear visual hierarchy between preview, timeline, and controls 3) Consistent iconography and color-coding for different track types. Deduct 3 points for poor contrast making content hard to see, 5 points for inconsistent or confusing UI elements, and 5 points for inefficient use of screen space. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the dynamic interaction smooth and seamless?
checklist.description: Judge whether the timeline scrubbing, track manipulation, and preview updates conform to professional editor standards: 1) Responsive preview updates (â‰¤ 200ms) 2) Smooth timeline scrolling and zooming 3) Drag-and-drop track manipulation with visual feedback. Deduct 5 points for laggy preview updates, 3 points for jerky timeline navigation, and 5 points for imprecise track manipulation controls. The full score is 10 points.
